Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: New Topics in Functional Data Analysis
Award.AbstractNarration:
Functional data are random vectors in a functional space, which are usually observed on discrete points and measured with error. Functional data are also deeply connected to other types of correlated data, such as spatial data, since they can both be modeled as stochastic processes. In the proposed research, the investigator will broaden the applications of functional data analysis by proposing a new functional data approach to model spatio-temporal point pattern data from disease surveillance applications, where the spatio-temporal random effects are modeled as latent functional processes. Motivated by scientific problems in colon carcinogenesis experiments and hypertension studies, the investigator proposes new dimension reduction methods, which are widely applicable to semiparametric regression problems with functional predictors. The investigator proposes new estimation procedures based on spline approximation and roughness penalties, and will also investigate the model selection and inference problems related to these methods. The investigator also proposes to model longitudinal clinical trial data by the functional analysis of covariance models, where different treatment effects are represented by nonparametric functions in time. The proposed nonparametric hypothesis test can be used to detect the treatment effects. Specifically, the investigator will study the effect of the within-subject correlation on the power of the test.

The proposed functional data approach to disease surveillance data will help to model the relationship between disease occurrence and some environmental variables (such as pollution level), estimate the time trend in the disease rate, and predict the unknown risk factors represented by latent random effects. The results will help disease control agencies and local officials to gain better understanding of the disease risk and develop better public health policies, such as emission or water quality control policies. The proposed dimension reduction methods provide the much needed statistical tools in the semiparametric regression problems in colon carcinogenesis and hypertension studies. The proposed nonparametric hypothesis testing procedure for functional analysis of covariance models answers a fundamental question in clinical trials, which is to compare the effectiveness of different treatments. The investigator will provide free and user-friendly software to scientific researchers and incorporate his research activity with graduate education. To further disseminate the research results and motivate new ideas, the investigator will develop a new course on functional data analysis and organize a research workshop.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project addresses statistical challenges arise from analyzing a new type of data called functional data, where the data are curves or images. Due to advances in new data collection technology and application of large scale surveys, these types of data become increasingly common in biological, medical, agricultural and industrial applications. With this project, the PI propose new statistical methodology and develop new theory to address important issues in functional data analysis, such as dimension reduction, joint modeling, clustering, nonlinear regression and the related model selection and statistical inference problems. This project results in a number of publications in top tier statistical journals, including Journal of the American Statistical Association, Journal of the Royal Statistical Society, Series B, and the Annals of Applied Statistics.

 

The proposed methodology was also applied to many scientific research areas. In a disease surveillance application, we model the spatio-temporal distribution of pancreatic cancer cases using a point process model and propose a latent functional data analysis approach to identified neighborhoods with unusual high cancer rates and mark these neighborhoods as hot spots on a map. These maps can help government agencies monitor disease outbreaks and distribution. In a substance abuse treatment application, we identify subgroups of drug users using the their longitudinal drug using patterns, and find patients in different subgroups have different relapse behaviors. These findings are potentially useful in developing personalized treatment regimens. In a gravitropism study in plant science, we model the longitudinal phenotype data of maze seeds as hierarchical functional data and find a lunar phase effect in root growth. For agriculture survey data, we also build a nonlinear regression model to predict crop yield use temperature trajectories and other land management information, which potentially has a big impact on agricultural economics and plant science.

 

Some other applications of our methodology include longitudinal data analysis from clinical trials and behavioral studies, driving trajectory studies, satellite image analysis and fMRI brain image data analysis. These applications not only demonstrate the usefulness of the new methodology but also lead to various new scientific findings. The project benefits the society by advancing knowledge in aforementioned scientific fields.

 

The project also help to build the future workforce by providing training opportunities for graduate students. The PI supervised dissertation research of seven Ph.D. students, who worked on various topics in this project. The PI also developed a new graduate level course on functional data analysis, which provides the students the exposure to cutting edge statistical theory and methods.
